ygData.subject: Introducing: The Creative Thinking Approach
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all, IÃ†m proud to announce a new paper on an idea I am really excited about, along with lead author Jingyu Li and co-author Jed Storie, titled:

Subject: Introducing: The Creative Thinking Approach
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=JAc4TYagxftzKC7hyXNKULE_VZa0b7An1u_n5Dhz0hSdcNMfYzUf
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_8073A214-3714-48D9-A01D-836B02283298
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello all,

I=92m proud to announce a new paper on an idea I am really exci=
ted about, along with lead author Jingyu Li and co-author Jed Storie, title=
d: "Encouraging creative thinking in robots improves their ability to solve=
 challenging problems.=94

Video: http://youtu.be/xik92wK8_gM 
PDF: http://=
goo.gl/njQTsG

The =93Creative Thinking Approach=94 involves getting robots=
 to =93think differently=94 about problems so that they can solve harder pr=
oblems. The general idea is to perform Novelty Search on the firing pattern=
s of hidden neurons, in addition to encouraging behavioral diversity. By en=
couraging different neural firing patterns, we can literally encourage nove=
l thoughts in the brains of robots; and, as we know from human problem solv=
ing, being able to think differently about a problem is often the key to so=
lving it. I personally believe this idea could be very helpful for our fiel=
d=92s goal of evolving much more complex behaviors. Our experiments show th=
at it increasingly helps on more difficult problems. 

Our paper also dovet=
ails nicely with Joel and Risto=92s recent paper, which does a great job of=
 laying out why many different types of =93cognitive behaviors=94 are decep=
tive (e.g. learning, memory, communication). I think the Creative Thinking =
Approach could really help with those problems, above and beyond the obviou=
s benefits provided by Novelty Search and/or Multi-Objective approaches tha=
t encourage Behavioral Diversity. 

This paper is the one that introduces t=
he concept of a =93novelty plateau=94, which is a condition in which mutati=
ons to the current population do not lead to new behaviors. If populations =
under Novelty Search are in such a condition, Novelty Search has no gradien=
t with which to reward stepping stones toward new behaviors. With the Creat=
ive Thinking Approach, however, the gradient still exists as long as variat=
ion in neural activity can be generated. 

Cite: 
Li J, Storie J, Clune J (=
2014) 
Encouraging creative thinking in robots improves their ability to so=
lve challenging problems. 
Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Comp=
utation Conference.

Abstract: Evolutionary algorithms frequently get stuck=
 on local optima=96and fail to find the global optimum=96when local gradien=
ts do not point the search process toward the direction of the global optim=
um. A recent breakthrough called Novelty Search ameliorates this problem by=
 enabling the search process to explore in every direction by encouraging t=
he production of novel, or not-yet-seen, phenotypes (e.g. new robot behavio=
rs). However, a problem with Novelty Search is that it can get lost on =93n=
ovelty plateaus=94 wherein novel behaviors in offspring are not immediately=
 produced by mutation and crossover (e.g. when a sequence of specific mutat=
ions is required to produce new behaviors, but the intermediate mutations a=
re not rewarded because they do not produce novel behaviors). In such cases=
, Novelty Search and related approaches that reward behavioral diversity ca=
n get stuck. Here we introduce a new approach, borrowed from human psycholo=
gy, that mitigates this problem: encouraging creative thinking. In addition=
 to rewarding novel behavior, we encourage evolving neural networks to =93t=
hink differently=94 by rewarding not-yet-seen firing patterns in hidden neu=
rons, which we call the =93Creative Thinking Approach.=94 We hypothesize th=
at encouraging novel thinking can reward stepping stones toward new behavio=
rs. On a variety of challenging robotic control problems from previous publ=
ications we demonstrate that, as problem difficulty increases, adding the C=
reative Thinking Approach increasingly improves performance over simply enc=
ouraging novel behaviors. Our results suggest that the Creative Thinking Ap=
proach could help improve the scale and complexity of problems that can be =
solved by evolutionary algorithms.

Finally, We=92d like to thank St=E9phan=
e Doncieux and Jean-Baptiste mouret for open-sourcing their nice code (ball=
 collecting and sferes) and for the great work they did on coming up with a=
 general behavioral metric based in input and output neural firing patterns=
, which our work builds on (conceptually, and in software). Their work can =
be found in this nice paper: http://goo.gl/IzcIH1  Thanks also to Charles O=
llion for help with animating these experiments. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clun=
e

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@uwy=
o.edu
jeffclune.com


--Apple-Mail=_8073A214-3714-48D9-A01D-836B02283298

ne_TheCreativeThinkingApproach_GECCO.pdf">http://goo.gl/njQTsG</a></div></d=
iv><div><br></div><div>The =93Creative Thinking Approach=94 involves gettin=
g robots to =93think differently=94 about problems so that they can solve h=
arder problems. The general idea is to perform Novelty Search on the firing=

y. By encouraging different neural firing patterns, we can literally encour=
age novel thoughts in the brains of robots; and, as we know from human prob=
lem solving, being able to think differently about a problem is often the k=
ey to solving it. I personally believe this idea could be very helpful for =
our field=92s goal of evolving much more complex behaviors. Our experiments=

v><br></div><div>Our paper also dovetails nicely with Joel and Risto=92s re=
cent paper, which does a great job of laying out why many different types o=
f =93cognitive behaviors=94 are deceptive (e.g. learning, memory, communica=
tion). I think the Creative Thinking Approach could really help with those =
problems, above and beyond the obvious benefits provided by Novelty Search =
and/or Multi-Objective approaches that encourage Behavioral Diversity.&nbsp=
;</div><div><br></div><div>This paper is the one that introduces the concep=
t of a =93novelty plateau=94, which is a condition in which mutations to th=
e current population do not lead to new behaviors. If populations under Nov=
elty Search are in such a condition, Novelty Search has no gradient with wh=
ich to reward stepping stones toward new behaviors. With the Creative Think=
ing Approach, however, the gradient still exists as long as variation in ne=
ural activity can be generated. </div><div><br></div><div>Cite: <=
/div><div>Li J, Storie J, Clune J (2014) </div><div>Encouraging creati=
ve thinking in robots improves their ability to solve challenging problems.=
 </div><div>Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Co=
nference.</div><div><br></div><div>Abstract: Evolutionary algorithms freque=
ntly get stuck on local optima=96and fail to find the global optimum=96when=
 local gradients do not point the search process toward the direction of th=
e global optimum. A recent breakthrough called Novelty Search ameliora=
tes this problem by enabling the search process to explore in every directi=
on by encouraging the production of novel, or not-yet-seen, phenotypes=
 (e.g. new robot behaviors). However, a problem with Novelty Search is that=
 it can get lost on =93novelty plateaus=94 wherein novel behaviors in offsp=
ring are not immediately produced by mutation and crossover (e.g. when=
 a sequence of specific mutations is required to produce new behaviors, but=
 the intermediate mutations are not rewarded because they do not produ=
ce novel behaviors). In such cases, Novelty Search and related approaches t=
hat reward behavioral diversity can get stuck. Here we introduce a new appr=
oach, borrowed from human psychology, that mitigates this problem: enc=
ouraging creative thinking. In addition to rewarding novel behavior, we enc=
ourage evolving neural networks to =93think differently=94 by rewardin=
g not-yet-seen firing patterns in hidden neurons, which we call the =93Crea=
tive Thinking Approach.=94 We hypothesize that encouraging novel thinking c=
an reward stepping stones toward new behaviors. On a variety of challe=
nging robotic control problems from previous publications we demonstrate th=
at, as problem difficulty increases, adding the Creative Thinking Appr=
oach increasingly improves performance over simply encouraging novel behavi=
ors. Our results suggest that the Creative Thinking Approach could help imp=
rove the scale and complexity of problems that can be solved by evolut=
ionary algorithms.</div><div><br></div><div>Finally, We=92d like to thank S=
t=E9phane Doncieux and Jean-Baptiste mouret for open-sourcing their nice co=
de (ball collecting and sferes) and for the great work they did on coming u=
p with a general behavioral metric based in input and output neural firing =
patterns, which our work builds on (conceptually, and in software). Their w=
ork can be found in this nice paper: <a href=3D"http://goo.gl/IzcIH1">=
http://goo.gl/IzcIH1</a>  Thanks also to Charles Ollion for help =
with animating these experiments. </div><div><div apple-content-edited=
